text_original:
SCAM ALERT: Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). 

These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA claiming that you owe the government back taxes. These scammers threaten arrest if you don't make an immediate payment through untraceable money transfers and prepaid credit cards.  

Always be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information. Here are some ways to tell if it's really the CRA: http://ow.ly/YExnK

#DYK being married or having a common-law partner can affect the amount of federal tax you pay on both your income and investments?

TIP: To maximize your tax credits, the person with the lower income should claim all of the couple's medical expenses on his or her tax return. This is because the federal government offers a non-refundable tax credit for expenses that are above a percentage (3% in 2015) of one partner's net income. Get more tax tips here: http://ow.ly/YnMeQ

status_message_cleaned: Have you ever had an item scan at a higher price at checkout than the one advertised or displayed? Did you know that if the item is under $10, you get it for free (first one only if you have more than one)? If the item is over $10, then you get $10 off the lowest advertised or displayed price. The next time this happens to you, ask if the retailer upholds the Scanner Price Accuracy Voluntary Code or look for the sign shown below at the entrance or checkout.

link_name: Find out about the new Canada child benefit
status_message_cleaned: Parents: the proposed new Canada child benefit (CCB) takes effect on July , . This benefit will be a tax-free, monthly payment based on your adjusted family net income. If you are already receiving child benefits, such as the universal child care benefit (UCCB) or the Canada child tax benefit (CCTB), or both, you do not have to apply for the Canada child benefit. Learn more about the new Canada child benefit: Additional information on child and family benefits:

text_original:
Parents: the proposed new Canada child benefit (CCB) takes effect on July 1, 2016. This benefit will be a tax-free, monthly payment based on your adjusted family net income.

If you are already receiving child benefits, such as the universal child care benefit (UCCB) or the Canada child tax benefit (CCTB), or both, you do not have to apply for the Canada child benefit.

Learn more about the new Canada child benefit: http://ow.ly/chFv301BWo3 

Additional information on child and family benefits: http://ow.ly/1ast301BWqv

status_message_cleaned: : A new scam targets millions of Canadian Netflix subscribers. Scammers send emails to Netflix clients posing as the company and direct them to a fake website “phishing” for their financial information. Never provide your credit card information unless you are using the company’s secure website. Protect yourself:

Scammers send emails to Netflix clients posing as the company and direct them to a fake website “phishing” for their financial information.

status_message_cleaned: : The Competition Bureau is urging consumers to be wary of deceptive tactics used by door-to-door salespeople trying to get you to sign a contract for a new water heater or heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system. These salespeople may misrepresent themselves as your current supplier, a local utility or the municipality when, in fact, they work for private companies that are unaffiliated with your current supplier or any government agency. Many use high-pressure tactics to get into your home, saying that an urgent inspection of your water heater or HVAC system is needed and demanding that you sign a contract with them on the spot. Unfortunately, once you enter into a long-term contract, it’s too late, leaving you to pay erbitant cancellation fees to get out of it. Get tips on how to avoid getting caught in this situation:

text_original:
#ConsumerAlert: The Competition Bureau is urging consumers to be wary of deceptive tactics used by door-to-door salespeople trying to get you to sign a contract for a new water heater or heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system.

These salespeople may misrepresent themselves as your current supplier, a local utility or the municipality when, in fact, they work for private companies that are unaffiliated with your current supplier or any government agency. Many use high-pressure tactics to get into your home, saying that an urgent inspection of your water heater or HVAC system is needed and demanding that you sign a contract with them on the spot. Unfortunately, once you enter into a long-term contract, it’s too late, leaving you to pay exorbitant cancellation fees to get out of it.

Get tips on how to avoid getting caught in this situation: http://ow.ly/4Ni9302wdjW

status_message_cleaned: : Have you received a “traffic violation ticket” by email? DO NOT PAY IT—IT’S A SCAM. This scam involves sending fake traffic tickets by email and asking for immediate payment through a link. Police do not issue tickets by email or even ask for your email during a traffic stop. Remember to never click on suspicious links or provide personal information to an untrusted source. Learn how to protect yourself from scams:

#ScamAlert:
Have you received a “traffic violation ticket” by email? 
DO NOT PAY IT—IT’S A SCAM.

This scam involves sending fake traffic tickets by email and asking for immediate payment through a link. Police do not issue tickets by email or even ask for your email during a traffic stop. 

Remember to never click on suspicious links or provide personal information to an untrusted source. 

Learn how to protect yourself from scams: http://ow.ly/SrRg306ATTq

link_name: Top 10 tips to protect your inbox, computer and mobile device
status_message_cleaned: Got spam? Avoid opening emails from unknown senders—and if you accidentally do, never reply. Replying confirms your address as being active and causes you to receive more spam. For the same reason, never click on a “remove” or “unsubscribe” link in a suspicious spam message. You may be unwittingly “subscribing” to receiving EVEN MORE spam. Check out these tips on how to protect your computer, inbox and mobile device:
text_filtered: Got spam Avoid opening emails unknown accidentally never reply Replying confirms address active causes receive spam reason never click link suspicious spam message may unwittingly receiving EVEN spam Check 10 tips protect computer inbox mobile device http ow ly Zm5V3
text_stemmed: [u'got', u'spam', u'avoid', u'open', u'email', u'unknown', u'accident', u'never', u'repli', u'repli', u'confirm', u'address', u'activ', u'caus', u'receiv', u'spam', u'reason', u'never', u'click', u'link', u'suspici', u'spam', u'messag', u'may', u'unwit', u'receiv', u'even', u'spam', u'check', '10', u'tip', u'protect', u'comput', u'inbox', u'mobil', u'devic', u'http', 'ow', 'ly', u'zm5v3']
text_original:
Got spam?

Avoid opening emails from unknown senders—and if you accidentally do, never reply. Replying confirms your address as being active and causes you to receive more spam. For the same reason, never click on a “remove” or “unsubscribe” link in a suspicious spam message. You may be unwittingly “subscribing” to receiving EVEN MORE spam. 

Check out these 10 tips on how to protect your computer, inbox and mobile device: http://ow.ly/Zm5V3

status_message_cleaned: : The CRA scam is back in full force. Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and claiming that you owe the government back taxes. These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA. If you receive a call, ask for the caller’s name, phone number and office location so that you can validate their identity BEFORE you give any personal information. Contact the CRA at -800-959-8281 to verify that the caller is legit. Be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information over the phone or by email. Here are some tips to tell if it’s really the CRA calling you: d

#ScamAlert: The CRA scam is back in full force.

Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and claiming that you owe the government back taxes. These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA. 

If you receive a call, ask for the caller’s name, phone number and office location so that you can validate their identity BEFORE you give any personal information. Contact the CRA at 1-800-959-8281 to verify that the caller is legit.

Be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information over the phone or by email. Here are some tips to tell if it’s really the CRA calling you: http://ow.ly/aaOV301UMld

Ahhh, #springcleaning, that time of year when we dig into our closets to clear out what we don’t need.

However, just like when donating money, you want to know where your donated items are going. For example, did you know that not all drop-off bins belong to non-profit organizations? 

Some signs give the impression that donations go directly to charity when they actually go to a FOR-PROFIT business.

Be wary of unsolicited emails or text messages asking you to call a number to get more information about a service or a promotion.

status_message_cleaned: : Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and claiming that you owe the government back taxes. These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA. If you receive a call, ask for the caller’s name, phone number and office location so that you can validate their identity BEFORE you give any personal information. Contact the CRA at -800-959-8281 to verify that the caller is legit. Remember to be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information over the phone or by email. Here are some tips to tell if it’s really the CRA calling you: d

#ScamAlert: Beware of scammers impersonating the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and claiming that you owe the government back taxes.

These scammers “spoof” phone numbers to make it look like the call is from the CRA. If you receive a call, ask for the caller’s name, phone number and office location so that you can validate their identity BEFORE you give any personal information. Contact the CRA at 1-800-959-8281 to verify that the caller is legit.

Remember to be vigilant when disclosing personal and financial information over the phone or by email. Here are some tips to tell if it’s really the CRA calling you: http://ow.ly/aaOV301UMld

status_message_cleaned: Do you have an “unclaimed balance” sitting in a long-forgotten savings or chequing account? An “unclaimed balance” occurs when there is no owner activity on an account for ten years and the owner cannot be reached by the institution. The balance is turned over to the Bank of Canada, which acts as custodian on behalf of the owner. Learn more about the types of unclaimed balances and find out if the Bank of Canada is holding one with your name on it :

text_original:
Do you have an “unclaimed balance” sitting in a long-forgotten savings or chequing account? 

An “unclaimed balance” occurs when there is no owner activity on an account for ten years and the owner cannot be reached by the institution. The balance is turned over to the Bank of Canada, which acts as custodian on behalf of the owner.

status_message_cleaned: : Do you know which services are included in your tuition fees? Knowing what you’re paying for can help you make smart money decisions. For example, tuition often includes fees for health and dental insurance, so if you’re already covered by similar insurance, you can save a few hundred dollars each school year by opting out. But don’t wait as there is often a cut-off for applying for these exclusions. Check out these other money saving tips for students:

#Students: Do you know which services are included in your tuition fees?

Knowing what you’re paying for can help you make smart money decisions. status_message_cleaned: Don’t you hate shopping for an item advertised as “on sale” to find it’s already sold out? If the bargain you seek is out of stock, ask for a rain check. This will allow you to get the deal once the item has been re-stocked. If a rain check is not offered and the seller cannot prove that the item was reasonably stocked or that it sold out due to reasons they were not able to control, it could be considered bait and switch selling—which is illegal. Learn more:

text_original:
Don’t you hate shopping for an item advertised as “on sale” to find it’s already sold out? 

If the bargain you seek is out of stock, ask for a rain check. This will allow you to get the deal once the item has been re-stocked.

If a rain check is not offered and the seller cannot prove that the item was reasonably stocked or that it sold out due to reasons they were not able to control, it could be considered bait and switch selling—which is illegal.

Learn more: http://ow.ly/uats3034uYN

status_message_cleaned: DYK? Banks aren’t permitted to pressure you into buying their products or services as a condition for obtaining another product or service from them? For example, if you apply for a mortgage at a bank, the institution cannot make you buy another product or service as a condition for obtaining the mortgage. This practice, called coercive tied selling, is illegal in Canada. If this happened to you and you want to file a complaint, contact the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada:
text_filtered: DYK Banks permitted pressure buying products services condition obtaining another product service example apply mortgage bank institution cannot make buy another product service condition obtaining mortgage practice called coercive tied selling illegal Canada happened want file complaint contact Financial Consumer Agency Canada http ow ly MmPR30b4eu3
text_stemmed: [u'dyk', u'bank', u'permit', u'pressur', u'buy', u'product', u'servic', u'condit', u'obtain', u'anoth', u'product', u'servic', u'exampl', u'appli', u'mortgag', u'bank', u'institut', u'cannot', u'make', u'buy', u'anoth', u'product', u'servic', u'condit', u'obtain', u'mortgag', u'practic', u'call', u'coerciv', u'tie', u'sell', u'illeg', u'canada', u'happen', u'want', u'file', u'complaint', u'contact', u'financi', u'consum', u'agenc', u'canada', u'http', 'ow', 'ly', u'mmpr30b4eu3']
text_original:
DYK? Banks aren’t permitted to pressure you into buying their products or services as a condition for obtaining another product or service from them?

For example, if you apply for a mortgage at a bank, the institution cannot make you buy another product or service as a condition for obtaining the mortgage. This practice, called coercive tied selling, is illegal in Canada.

If this happened to you and you want to file a complaint, contact the Financial Consumer Agency of Canada: http://ow.ly/MmPR30b4eu3

status_message_cleaned: If a tree falls on your house, are you covered? Answer: It depends. Homeowner insurance typically protects against specific perils such as fire or theft, but damage that could have been prevented through proper maintenance typically isn’t covered. That means if the tree is rotting or you failed to prune it as needed, you may be out a whole lot of green. A little DIY now can save you uneected costs in the long run. Learn how to properly prune your trees:

text_original:
If a tree falls on your house, are you covered? 

Answer: It depends. 

Homeowner insurance typically protects against specific perils such as fire or theft, but damage that could have been prevented through proper maintenance typically isn’t covered. That means if the tree is rotting or you failed to prune it as needed, you may be out a whole lot of green. 

A little DIY now can save you unexpected costs in the long run. Learn how to properly prune your trees: http://ow.ly/9frW303WqYS

status_message_cleaned: Have you received a notice about potential copyright infringement from your Internet service provider? It may have been forwarded to you as part of the Notice and Notice regime to discourage online copyright infringement. However, receiving a notice doesn’t necessarily mean you will be sued and you are not obligated to respond. The notice should contain information that will help you understand the details of the allegation, which could be referring to acts carried out by someone using your Internet connection without your knowledge. Learn more about Notice and Notice and what it means for you:

Have you received a notice about potential copyright infringement from your Internet service provider?  

It may have been forwarded to you as part of the Notice and Notice regime to discourage online copyright infringement. However, receiving a notice doesn’t necessarily mean you will be sued and you are not obligated to respond. The notice should contain information that will help you understand the details of the allegation, which could be referring to acts carried out by someone using your Internet connection without your knowledge.

Learn more about Notice and Notice and what it means for you: http://ow.ly/XvO75

status_message_cleaned: : PayPal scams are on the rise. Fraudsters target people selling items online by pretending to be interested buyers. #ScamAlert: PayPal scams are on the rise.

Fraudsters target people selling items online by pretending to be interested buyers. They send fake emails to online sellers, “phishing” for PayPal account details. 

Don’t take the bait! These scammers want to get access to your financial information. PayPal will never ask for your credit card information or account password by email. 

Learn to protect yourself from scammers preying on unsuspecting online sellers: http://ow.ly/uEwd30f3YoZ

status_message_cleaned: Are you a federal government employee on the Phoenix payroll system? If you receive a call from somebody seeking to collect overpayments, do not provide any personal information, such as your address or your credit card or bank account number, and do not make payment arrangements with the caller. This is a scam. The Government of Canada is not using collection agencies to collect overpayments related to Phoenix. Report the call to the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre.

If you receive a call from somebody seeking to collect overpayments, do not provide any personal information, such as your address or your credit card or bank account number, and do not make payment arrangements with the caller. This is a scam.

 
The Government of Canada is not using collection agencies to collect overpayments related to Phoenix. Report the call to the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre. http://ow.ly/TcYa306WgHb

status_message_cleaned: Be wary of “secret shopper” job opportunities. While legit secret shopper jobs do exist, there are lots of fake offers for these gigs. Scammers often contact you via spam email claiming that the job is quick and easy AND that it pays well. They then ask you to pay a fee upfront for a bogus “shopping certification.” Bottom line? If you have to pay a fee to take on a new job, chances are it’s a scam.

While legit secret shopper jobs do exist, there are lots of fake offers for these gigs. Scammers often contact you via spam email claiming that the job is quick and easy AND that it pays well. They then ask you to pay a fee upfront for a bogus “shopping certification.”

If you’re looking for a summer job or you want to work while attending a post-secondary school, consider applying to the Federal Student Work Experience Program (FSWEP).

FSWEP is a great opportunity for full-time students to explore their interests, develop skills AND make some extra money. A placement through the program is also a great start for anyone considering a career in the public service.

The process is ongoing and some departments start their selection for summer 2017 as early as this August.

Learn more about FSWEP and submit your application today: http://ow.ly/7mGg301BYgW

status_message_cleaned: Been asked to dial a telephone number? Be wary of unsolicited emails or text messages asking you to call a number to get more information about a service or promotion. text_original:
Been asked to dial a 900 telephone number? 

Be wary of unsolicited emails or text messages asking you to call a number to get more information about a service or promotion.

Typically, 900 and 976 numbers are pay-per-call services, which means you’re paying for calls originating from or charged to your telephone, no matter who made the calls or accepted the charges. 

You can request a call-blocking feature from your telephone company. Learn more: http://ow.ly/gJus30ejL0b

Through the Canada Education Savings Grant, the Government adds money to your kid’s Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP) to help his or her savings grow. To be eligible for the grant, you must start to save for your child’s #RESP before the end of the calendar year in which he or she turns 15 years of age. 

Find out how to apply: http://ow.ly/ROv530eaqca

Think counterfeiting is a new problem? Think again! 

#WeirdHistoricalFact: Canadians became infamously good at counterfeiting our own and U.S. bills as early as the 1850s. 

Though the practice was refined over the course of Canada’s history, the RCMP reports that thanks to new security features, circulation of counterfeit bills dropped by 74% the year after our polymer bills were released.

status_message_cleaned: If a tree falls on your house, does your insurance cover the damage? Answer: It depends. Learn how to properly prune your trees:

If a tree falls on your house, does your insurance cover the damage?  
Answer: It depends. 

Homeowner insurance typically protects against specific perils such as fire or theft, but damage that could have been prevented through proper maintenance isn’t usually covered. That means if the tree is rotting or you failed to prune it as needed, you may be out a whole lot of green. 

A little DIY now can save you unexpected costs in the long run. Learn how to properly prune your trees: http://ow.ly/ScY430db9HZ

#Students: Moving away from home is an exciting time for you—AND for scammers!  

Be cautious of hijacked rental ads in which scammers pose as landlords, refer you to real listings and offer to beat the listed price. Scammers will often claim to be out of the country and ask for a security deposit or the first month’s rent before you even meet them or sign a lease.

If you suspect that you may be the target of fraud or you have already sent funds, don't be embarrassed—contact the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre or your local police: http://ow.ly/bsnx302AR20

status_message_cleaned: Have you received a notice from your Internet service provider about potential copyright infringement? Don’t panic. status_message_cleaned: Suffering bill shock from a shared or family wireless plan? While regulations ensure that service providers cap data overage charges to $50 a month, any plan member can authorize charges above the cap—even kids! Avoid costly surprises by laying out your house rules for making authorizations to family plans. If you received a bill with overage charges you did not authorize, submit a complaint to the Commissioner for Complaints for Telecommunications Services (CCTS):

While regulations ensure that service providers cap data overage charges to $50 a month, any plan member can authorize charges above the cap—even kids! Avoid costly surprises by laying out your house rules for making authorizations to family plans. 

If you received a bill with overage charges you did not authorize, submit a complaint to the Commissioner for Complaints for Telecommunications Services (CCTS): http://ow.ly/Bkm7301UDDH

status_message_cleaned: Don’t you hate shopping for an item that’s advertised as “on sale” only to find it’s already sold out? If the bargain item you seek is out of stock, ask for a rain check so you can still get the deal once the item has been restocked. If a rain check is not offered and the seller can’t prove the item was reasonably stocked or that it sold out due to reasons beyond the seller’s control, it could be considered bait and switch selling, which is illegal. Learn more:

If you receive a pension, you may be able to allocate up to 50% of your eligible pension income to your spouse or common-law partner to reduce the taxes that you pay; however, both of you must jointly elect to do this.

status_message_cleaned: Limited time offer! All you need to do is sign up! We know what you’re thinking: IT’S A TRAP! A subscription trap, that is. The shoulder season, the travel period between the peak and off seasons, offers lower rates for great vacation spots without the peak season crowds.

http://www.consumerhandbook.ca/en/topics/products-and-services/travel

status_message_cleaned: Whether you need television, Internet, mobile or phone services, it’s all about choices. So what do you do if you run into resistance when trying to change service providers? Don’t forget that interest rates and costs associated with a reverse mortgage are usually higher than those of a regular mortgage. The equity you hold in your home may go down as the interest on your loan adds up over the years. Learn more: http://ow.ly/p2sE30cqMT6

text_original:
Is your mortgage up for renewal?

Don’t wait for your renewal letter to start shopping around. A little advance legwork can lead to big savings over the course of one mortgage term. Take the time to find the mortgage that’s best for you by seeing what other lenders have to offer. Don’t forget, you can also negotiate rates with your current lender to save money. 

More information about mortgage renewal: http://ow.ly/4n3L9O

#DYK that leaving the hose running when washing your car uses about 400 litres of water per car wash?

Here’s a quick way to #Save5: Use a bucket of soapy water to wash your car and only use the hose to rinse it off. That’ll reduce your water usage by about 75%, which means savings on your water bill. 

Learn more on how to best watch your water consumption: http://ow.ly/7yDX300U133 #CanadianEnvironmentWeek

status_message_cleaned: If you’re a concertgoer or sports fan looking to buy tickets online, be wary of cyber criminals. These fraudsters will try to scam you out of your money or steal your personal info. Make sure the ticketing website has sales, return and privacy policies. Also, check to see if there is a real physical address and phone number for the business. Legit websites will have all those bases covered. More tips on buying event tickets online:

text_original:
If you’re a concertgoer or sports fan looking to buy tickets online, be wary of cyber criminals. These fraudsters will try to scam you out of your money or steal your personal info. Legit websites will have all those bases covered.

More tips on buying event tickets online: http://ow.ly/7vu130cQ21R

text_original:
Residents of British Columbia:

The Supreme Court of BC has confirmed that debt collectors must stop attempting to contact debtors by phone if they have requested communication to be in writing only. This includes being contacted using an auto-dialer once you’ve asked for calls to stop.

status_message_cleaned: Should you care about your credit score? Short answer: yes. Long answer: yes. Your credit report is a history of how you have met your financial obligations. The higher your score, the more likely you are to be approved for loans, credit cards and lower interest rates. A low credit score could lead to problems when trying to rent an apartment or even prevent you from getting a job you want! Get more details on why your credit score matters and how to find out yours:

text_original:
Should you care about your credit score? 

Short answer: yes. Long answer: yes.  

Your credit report is a history of how you have met your financial obligations. The higher your score, the more likely you are to be approved for loans, credit cards and lower interest rates. A low credit score could lead to problems when trying to rent an apartment or even prevent you from getting a job you want! 

Get more details on why your credit score matters and how to find out yours: http://ow.ly/YED5R

In 2016, a total of 3.2 billion cans, 2.1 billion bottles and 41.1 million kegs of beer were sold in Canada. In fact, Canadians consume an average of 77.1 litres of beer per capita each year!

Quiz time: Do you know which one of these is a pint?

If you said “B,” you are correct! But did you know the margin of error for a 20 fl. oz. beer is 0.5 fl. oz.? If you plan to order a pint for #InternationalBeerDay, make sure you #getwhatyoupayfor.

status_message_cleaned: Are you a recent college or university graduate? CONGRATS! For the first six months after you leave school, you don’t have to make payments on your Canada Student Loan or your provincial student loan. But remember that interest DOES accumulate during this period. Now’s the time to make a plan for repaying your student debt. Are you a recent college or university graduate? CONGRATS!

For the first six months after you leave school, you don’t have to make payments on your Canada Student Loan or your provincial student loan. But remember that interest DOES accumulate during this period.

Now’s the time to make a plan for repaying your student debt. You will need to know the total amount you owe, the interest rate that will be applied to your debt and how long it will take to pay back your debt.

Learn more about paying back Canada Student Loans: http://ow.ly/j3kN30bDPUH

status_message_cleaned: When you’re shopping, be cautious of marketing strategies designed to make you buy more than you need. You may run into offers such as “BOGO—buy one item and get a second half off!” This may seem like a good deal, but in order to take advantage of it, you need to spend more than you originally planned. Plus, in the end you’re only getting half a deal when you have to buy twice as many shoes. More wise spending habits:

status_message_cleaned: Are Bitcoins considered a real currency in Canada? Bitcoins are a digital currency that is not controlled by any central bank, institution or country. It allows users to connect directly to each other and transfer Bitcoins anonymously for goods and services using digital “wallets.” Only Canadian bank notes and coins are recognized as currency and eligible to be used as legal tender in Canada. Barter transaction rules apply where Bitcoins are used to purchase goods or services. Get more details here:

Are Bitcoins considered a real currency in Canada? 

Bitcoins are a digital currency that is not controlled by any central bank, institution or country. It allows users to connect directly to each other and transfer Bitcoins anonymously for goods and services using digital “wallets.”

Only Canadian bank notes and coins are recognized as currency and eligible to be used as legal tender in Canada. Barter transaction rules apply where Bitcoins are used to purchase goods or services. 

Get more details here: http://ow.ly/po0C309zkhl

Items like electronics and personal devices bought from a foreign retailer online may come with a warranty that doesn’t protect you at home in Canada. That means you may be on the hook for repairing or replacing the product if it breaks—even if the same product is available or for sale in our country. http://ow.ly/kQ5Z30eQVJo

status_message_cleaned: Treat your next vacation like an investment, and protect it by booking with a licensed travel agent. In British Columbia, travel agents are required to be licensed and must contribute to the Travel Assurance Fund. Consumers who book with a licensed agent can make a claim to the fund if they do not receive the services they purchased and are unable to obtain compensation through their travel insurance, credit card or other sources. Get more information about your travel rights from :

text_original:
Treat your next vacation like an investment, and protect it by booking with a licensed travel agent.

In British Columbia, travel agents are required to be licensed and must contribute to the Travel Assurance Fund. Consumers who book with a licensed agent can make a claim to the fund if they do not receive the services they purchased and are unable to obtain compensation through their travel insurance, credit card or other sources.

Get more information about your travel rights from @ConsumerProtectionBC: http://ow.ly/ZFPew

status_message_cleaned: Do you have overland flood coverage? This type of coverage is an additional insurance item to protect against overland flooding from heavy rainfall or snowmelt runoff, for example. Many home insurance policies don’t actually cover overland flooding. Most homes are only covered for water damage or loss from burst water pipes or sewage backup.

This type of coverage is an additional insurance item to protect against overland flooding from heavy rainfall or snowmelt runoff, for example.

status_message_cleaned: : Scams can be disguised as text messages promoting free or trial offers. These “offers” often come with a catch: a charge on your next credit card statement or phone bill. Planning a move? Choosing the right moving company can make all the difference!

Before hiring a company, do your research. Get quotes from at least three reliable movers in your area so you can compare options and costs. Scam operators lure customers in with cut-rate prices and grandiose promises. Then they inflate the price on moving day, holding your stuff for ransom.

With a new job comes your own money and the freedom to decide how to spend it. Even if you don’t get paid on a regular schedule or if your job is temporary, take steps to start saving.

status_message_cleaned: Bought an item from a private seller at a garage sale or via online classifieds but it’s not living up to eectations? text_original:
Bought an item from a private seller at a garage sale or via online classifieds but it’s not living up to expectations?

Private sales are NOT covered under most provincial and territorial consumer protection laws. If something goes wrong, you will likely need to deal with the seller directly. If the seller isn’t willing to work things out, your next step may be small claims court. 

Learn more about the risks of private sales: http://ow.ly/s8Zs30cELkn

Looking to buy a home worth more than $500K? 

As of February 15, 2016, Canadians who buy a home over $500K must pay an additional amount on their down payment. This means the minimum down payment for a new, insured mortgage is 5%, plus 10% of the portion priced above $500,000.

Use our  mortgage qualifier tool to help determine how much you could qualify for, based on your income and expenses: http://ow.ly/4mO7mC
